N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 20 ยง 2400.1 - General

State Regulations

Tax Law, ยง 3032
(a) In general, a taxpayer may bring a civil action for damages against the State
in the Court of Claims where any officer or employee of the Department of

Taxation and Finance knowingly, or by reason of negligence, fails to release a
lien on property of the taxpayer within 40 days after the date: (1)
on which the Commissioner of Taxation and

Finance finds full satisfaction or legal unenforce ability of the liability
assessed or determined, including interest; or
(2)
there is furnished to the commissioner a
surety bond or other security that is conditioned upon the payment of the
amount assessed or determined, including interest (see, section
2400.3
of
this Part). (b) For
purposes of subdivision (a) of this section, full satisfaction of the liability
assessed or determined occurs when: (1)
the
commissioner determines that the entire liability listed in the state tax
warrant has been fully satisfied (such determination will be made as soon as
practicable after tender of payment); or
(2)
the taxpayer submits to the commissioner, in writing, a request for a release of lien which shall contain: (i) the name and address of the
taxpayer; (ii)
a copy of the state
tax warrant affecting the property; and
(iii)
the grounds upon which the issuance of
a release is sought (including proof of full payment, where
applicable). Notes
